titleStmt.title: A description of Mother Ludwell's cave1`In the pleasure grounds of Moor Park, Surrey, Sr Wm Temple's Seat' (note on the MS. perhaps written by the late Mrs. F. L. Longe).

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: hæ latebræ dulces, et si mihi credis, amœnæ1hæ latebræ dulces, et si mihi credis, amœnæ. Horace, Epist. I. xvi. 15: `Hae latebrae dulces, etiam, si credis, amoenae.' In the MS. this motto precedes A Description, &c

R074$3X1 1 lett others with Parnassus swell their theam, R074$3X1 2 drinke inspiration from th' Aonian1Aonian. Aonia was that part of Boeotia which contained Mount Helicon (treated in English poetry as a stream) and the fountain Aganippe. stream:R074$3X1 3 lett them draw Phoebus down to patch a line,R074$3X1 4 invoke, that hackney fry,2that hackney fry. Cp. Swift, Ode to Sir William Temple, VII: `as in a theatre the ignorant fry.' the tunefull nine:R074$3X1 5 I that of Ludwell sing, to Ludwell run,R074$3X1 6 her self my muse, her spring my Helicon.R074$3X1 7 the neighbouring park its friendly aid allows;R074$3X1 8 perfum'd with thyme, o'erspread with shadie boughs;R074$3X1 9 its leafie canopys new thoughts instill,R074$3X1 10 and Crooksberry3Crooksberry, a hill close to Moor Park. supplies the cloven hill.4the cloven hill, Parnassus with its two peaks, the seat of the Muses.R074$3X1 11 Pomona does Minervas stores dispence,5Pomona does Minervas stores dispense. If the line is sound, can it mean that Pomona is the agent of Temple, whose skill in fruit-tree lore was so well known? He chose the trees and gave them scientific culture, and Pomona then produced the apples.R074$3X1 12 And Flora sheds her balmie influence;R074$3X1 13 all things conspire to press my modest Muse,R074$3X1 14 the morning herbs adorn'd with pearly dews,R074$3X1 15 the meadows interlaced with silver flouds,6the meadows interlaced with silver flouds, i.e. the Wey running through the water-meadows between Moor Park and Waverley (Sir A.H.).R074$3X1 16 the frizled thickets,7the frizled thickets. Cp. Milton, P.L. vii. 323: `And bush with frizzled haire implicit.' The reference is rather to the curled leaves than to their rustling sound. and the taller woods.R074$3X1 17 the whisp'ring Zephyrs my more silent tongueR074$3X1 18 correct, and Philomela chirps a song.8Philomela chirps a song. Had the writer of these words ever heard a nightingale?R074$3X1 19 is there a bird of all the blooming year,R074$3X1 20 that has not sung his early Mattins here?R074$3X1 21 that has not sip'd the Fairy Matrons9the Fairy Matrons. `Fairy', as in `fairy godmother', with no suggestion of diminutive size. spring,R074$3X1 22 or hover'd o'er her cave with wishfull wing?R074$3X1 23 an awfull Fabrick built by Natures handR074$3X1 24 does raise our wonder, our respect command.R074$3X1 25 three lucky trees to wilder art10wilder art. Nature is here less wild than Art: no gardener could get so artistic an effect. unknownR074$3X1 26 seem on the front a growing triple crown.R074$3X1 27 at first the arched room is high and wide,R074$3X1 28 the naked walls with mossie hangings hid;R074$3X1 29 the cieling sandy: as you forward pressR074$3X1 30 the roof is still declining into less;R074$3X1 31 despair to reach the end──a little archR074$3X1 32 narrow and low forbids yr utmost search.R074$3X1 33 so to her lover the chaste, beauteous lassR074$3X1 34 without a blush vouchsafes to shew her face,R074$3X1 35 her neck of Ivory, her snowy breast,R074$3X1 36 these shown, she modestly conceals the rest.R074$3X1 37 A shallow brook, that restless under groundR074$3X1 38 strugled with earth, here a moist passage found.R074$3X1 39 down thro' a stony vein the waters rowlR074$3X1 40 o'erflowing the capacious iron bowl:R074$3X1 41 oh! happy bowl, that gladness can infuse,R074$3X1 42 and yet was never stain'd with heady juice.R074$3X1 43 Here thirsty souls carouse with innocence,R074$3X1 44 nor owe their pleasure to their loss of sence.R074$3X1 45 Here a smooth floor had many a figure shown,R074$3X1 46 had Virgin footsteps made impression,R074$3X1 47 that soft and swift Camilla-like advance,11had Virgin footsteps made impression,_that soft and swift Camilla-like advance._Virgil says of Camilla (Aen. vii. 808, 9): `Illa vel intactae segetis per summa volaret Gramina; nec teneras cursu laesisset aristas.' This Swift recalls in his poem Sir William Temple's late Illness and Recovery written in December 1693: `Time o'er the happy takes so swift a flight, And treads so soft, so easy and so light, That we the wretched, creeping far behind, Can scarce th' impression of his footsteps find; Smooth as that airy nymph so subtly born[e] With inoffensive feet o'er standing corn.'_Were there two poets writing at Moor Park at the same time, whose minds separately recurred to Camilla? Or was Jonathan Swift the author of the `description of Mother Ludwells cave'? He refers to the cave in his lines to Mr. Congreve of the same year 1693: `Here by a mountain's side, a reverend cave Gives murmuring passage to a lasting wave.' Pope's reference to the light-footed lady in Essay on Criticism, ll. 372, 3 and Sir Walter Scott's in The Lady of the Lake, I. xviii, are familiar to most people.R074$3X1 48 while even movements seem to fly a dance.12while even movements seem to fly a dance. The line is difficult. I consider `a dance' as a cognate accusative. `Fly a dance'=`dance a dance'.R074$3X1 49 no quilted couch, the sickmans daily bed,R074$3X1 50 no seats to lull asleep diseases made,R074$3X1 51 are seen; but such as healthy persons pleaseR074$3X1 52 of wood or stone,13seats . . . of wood or stone. These seats, the iron bowl that received the waters from the inner cavern and overflowed with them, and the oaks mentioned in the other poem on the cave, are all well seen in the print of 1785. such as the wearied ease.R074$3X1 53 O might I still enjoy this peacefull gloom!R074$3X1 54 the truest entrance to Elizium.R074$3X1 55 who would to the Cumaean den14the Cumaean den, the cave at Cumae where Aeneas met the Sibyl, Aen. vi. 42. repaire?R074$3X1 56 a better Sybil, wiser power is here.R074$3X1 57 Methinks I see him from his palace come,R074$3X1 58 and with his presence grace ye balefull room:R074$3X1 59 Consider, Ludwell, what to him you owe,R074$3X1 60 who does for you the noisy court forego;15Consider, Ludwell, what to him you owe_who does for you the noisy court forego._This again resembles Swift's Ode to Sir William Temple Written at Moor-Park in June 1689, stanza ix:_`Sing, beloved Muse! the pleasures of retreat . . ._Go, publish o'er the plain_How mighty a proselyte you gain!_How noble a reprisal on the great!'_Swift goes on to say that the Muse whom he invokes to leave the Thames for Moor Park at length `softly steals in many windings down, As loth to see the hated court and town'. Sir William Temple had left Sheen for Moor Park in 1681 after his son's marriage, had returned to Sheen during the troubles of the Revolution, and finally settled at Moor Park after his son's death in 1689. Swift lived with him at Moor Park from 1689 to 1691, from Feb. 1692 to May 1694, and from May 1696 till Temple's death on 26 Jan. 1698/9._The expression `debauch'd by praise' in stanza xii of this Ode is again an echo of l. 72 of the poem before us: `debauch'd by art.'R074$3X1 61 nay he a rich and gaudy silence16a rich and gaudy silence. Temple has not only abandoned the Court, but his pleasant retirement at Sheen. leaves,R074$3X1 62 you share ye honour, sweet Moorparke receives.R074$3X1 63 you with yr wrinkles admiration move,R074$3X1 64 that with its beauty better merits love.R074$3X1 65 Here's careless Nature in her ancient dress,R074$3X1 66 there she·'s more modish,17modish. Swift speaks of `the new modish system' in his Ode to the Athenian Society. & consults ye glass.R074$3X1 67 Here she·'s an old, but yet a pleasant dame;R074$3X1 68 there she'l a fair, not painted Virgin seem.R074$3X1 69 Here the rich Mettal hath through no fire pass'd,R074$3X1 70 there, tho refin'd, by no allay debas'd.R074$3X1 71 Thus nature is preserv'd in every part,R074$3X1 72 sometimes adorn'd, but nere debauch'd by art.R074$3X1 73 When scatter'd locks, that dangle on the brow,R074$3X1 74 into more decent hairy circles grow,R074$3X1 75 after enquiry made, tho no man loveR074$3X1 76 the curling iron, all the comb approve.R074$3X1
